Posts.Content: Hello, Am I glad that I found this site!!! Here is a letter that I had just sent to the Canadian Cancer Society. I am putting it here Hello, Yesterday I received quite a surprise. I learned that my PSA blood test results was over 300. (both the initial and confirmation test). I had read your pamphlet on the topic. However in the literature that I could get access to there is no mention anywhere of these type of numbers in the hundreds. Of course I searched for this topic on the internet. I would like your help to guide me towards credible reports and information that deal more directly with the type of results that I just received. My GP is a great person and she contacted me immediately after getting the first results and she just asked me to quickly get another test. Now she is in the process of having me see a urologist and asked if I had any reserves about a nuclear test for my bones. I live in a small community and that person is on holidays this week. I have to admit that I am not afraid of dying. Just last week I got lost in the local mountains. I had to spend the night, all wet, sitting and shivering on my skis till daylight not knowing if my body would produce enough heat to keep me alive. There was no panic and I was in peace, like I am now, with the idea of dying. The only regret would have been to dye because of such a silly mistake. The next day there was enough energy left to allow me to self rescue out of that situation. I just want a clear picture to help me, in consultation with my wife, to make judicious decisions adapted to our own situation. Many years ago, my wife has been a pioneer when she was the first person to receive Avastin to treat wet macula degeneration. Now this is the accepted treatment in BC. I would be delighted to add some sense to my misfortune by contributing to any research that might be adapted to my situation. I am looking forward to hearing from you. Regards, Paul Picard 250-362-7642
Posts.Title: Just got a PSA reading of 300

Posts.Content: Hello Replicant, Thank you very much for the links. One of them allowed me to understand more the humor of a posting that I came across somewhere when the person said that he lit up like a Xmas tree when he passed the bone scan. I am scheduled for a Bone Scan first thing Monday Morning. Thanks Paul Picard
Posts.Title: Just got a PSA reading of 300

Posts.Content: Is there a way to edit the title of my thread? to Just got my PSA reading of over 300 today
Posts.Title: Just got a PSA reading of 300

Posts.Content: Is there a way to edit the title of my thread? to Just got my PSA reading of over 300 today
Posts.Title: Just got a PSA reading of 300

Posts.Content: Thanks for changing the title. So much information is for lower scores. Most statistics and tables deal with the "normal" occurrences. I am wondering what percentage of test results are in the 300+ category. I can see by the stepping immediately to the bone scan even before the biopsy what is expected. Part of the picture to accept is the life expectancy and also the expected quality of life. I know that each case is different however statistics show at least a grouping picture of the situation. I came across 28% live up to 5 years. What could they do in those five years? I just can't wait to get the bone scan and I look forward to getting an appointment for the biopsy. I will definitely keep you posted. It helps me a lot also to follow what happens in other threads. Regards, Paul

Posts.Title: Just got a PSA reading of 300

Posts.Content: Hello, I am 66 years old and a very active retired person. My health is fine with no problems besides some arthritis in some joints that tempers somewhat my skiing, tennis, hiking and cycling. Today I learned that I had a PSA reading above 300! I did not really know what it meant until I started doing some research on the web. It seems like bad news. I am really symptom free. I am looking forward to have a more complete picture of the situation. I don't think that I will try to fight at all cost to extend my life if it does not come with a certain quality of life and a minimum of pain. I have no children or grand children. I still know really nothing about this topic that as soon as this morning was not even on my radar scope. I would like get more information about PSA scores in the hundreds. Regards, Paul Picard
